document.text: Xmas holidays passed off very quietly. Lots of visitors came back to spend Xmas with the home folk and some went away for the holidays. Quite a numoer of parties for the younger set Miss Virginia Chick entertained a number her friends at a birthday party on the evening of the 26th. Mis Hazel Taylorwas hostess to the younger set Monday night. The flu epidemic is quite serl ous around here. Some families are ali in bed. The schools wi remain closed until an. 17th on account of flu. Rev. A. I. Caudle spent Sat night with Mr. W. S. Taylor and family. On account of flu there was no services at Hebron last Sunday. Rev. Caudle motorec to Durham, N. C-, Sunday p. m or his family, where they were spending the holidays. Mr. J. H. Elder and family, lrs. G. A. Jacobs and children returned to Richmond Sunday after spending the holidays with Mr. and Mrs. C- M. Stratton. Miss Hazel Taylor left Sunday or Richmond to resume her duties in school. Mrs. J T. Whitten spent part of the holidays in High 3oint, N. C., with her daughter Mrs. Whitten is sick with flu. Mrs. J. W. Neighbors visitec her son, Jim, in Lynchburg few days last week. Mr. and Mrs. W. D. Parris are happy over the arrival of their twins, boy and a girl. Mr. and Mrs- C. M. Stratton spent Wednesday with their daughter, Mrs. D. A. Christian Mr. and Mrs. S. E. Anderson Mrs. C. M. Stratton, Mr. and Mrs. W. H. Drinkard, Mr, anc Mrs. C. T. Drinkard and Cla,yton Jr., attended the funeral of S P. Taylor in Bedford county Monday. Rev. H. B. Jennings Jr., of Leesburg, was Xmas guest of his brother, F. E. Jennings and family. Parks Jennings returned from Richmond Saturday nite after a stay of several weeks. While there tie contracted flu and re mained longer than expected Mrs. Jennings and four children were all in bed with flu when he reached home. Glad to say they are improving. Doctors are kept busy in this community as there is so much sickness. Mr. and Mrs. Clayton Drink ard and Clayton, Jr., returned Thursday from Franklin, where they spent the holidays. Miss Annie Alvis left Tuesday for Farmville, after spending the holidays at home.. She had as her guests Miss Alice Street Davis and Jeffers Street o f Lowesville, and Miss Evelyn Smith of Farmville. Prof. Kenneth Alvis of Athens Ga., visited home people Xmas.

document.text: WALTER HENRY NAMED PRESIDENT OF LOCAL METHODIST CLUB A new organization of Methodist Men in Meomrial Methodist Church, Appomattox, has been chartered by Methodisms General Board of Lay Activities in Chicago. Officers of the new group are Walter Henry, Appomattox, presi dent Fred Smith, Appomattox, vice president R. B. Parris, Jr., Appo mattox, secretary. The local group is one of more I than 7,000 Methodist Men organi zations out of a total goal of 10, 000 clubs which the board plans to charter by 1956. It is estimated that 2,000,000 men in the Methodist Church are pros pective members of Methodist Men clubs. Robert G. Mayfield, executive secretary of the board, states that, We seek to mobilize through Meth odist Men the tremendous power and enthusiam of the men of the church. Our purpose is to give strength to the program of Christ and His Church through consecra ted service of men in every local curch of Methodism.

document.text: United States Senator Harry F. Byrd, Jr. spoke at Lonwood Colleges graduation cere monies on Saturday, May 13th. Senator Byrd has spent 30 years in government, serving in the Virginia Senate fpr 18 years prior to his appointment to the U. S. Senate in 1965. He was , elected senator in 1966, and re-elected in 1970 and 1976. Senator Byrd. was introduced i by Mrs. Raymond E. Brown, Jr., of Hampton, rector of Longwoods Board of Visitors. A total of 446 degrees were  awarded, including 392 bacca-  laureate degrees and 54 1 masters degrees. This was the largest number of graduate j degrees awarded by Longwood since the graduate program was authorized in 1954. The diplomas were presented by Longwoods president, Dr. Henry I. Willett, Jr., and vice president for academic affairs. Dr. Carolyn Wells. Area students receiving degrees were Dennis Gene Clarkson of Pamplin, B. document.text: United States marines lay claim to being the best fed of the worlds fighting men. And it is easy to see why the Leathernecks believe their chow is so superior. A menu picked at random from any marine base throughout the country is a good il lustration. Heres onebreakfast at the ma rine corps training station at Parris Island, S. C. oatmeal with cream, bacon and eggs, fried potatoes, but tered toast, coffee and fruit. And heres what the boys at Quan- tico, Va., had for dinner on Sunday, September 12 roast turkey with dressing and giblet gravy, mashed potatoes, buttered string beans, to mato and lettuce salad, bread and butter and ice cream. Another sample menu will round out the day. This is a typical Sun day evening meal cold cuts, baked beans, sliced cheese, beet and onion salad, bread and butter, doughnuts and coffee. Each and every meal prepared for the fightinest body of men on earth can well satisfy the most ex acting gourmet. Carefully designed menus of at tractive and well-prepared food nec essary for the needs of these sea going soldiers is an every-meal proj ect. It is most important that the food give the number of vitamins and calories required by the nature of their work. The amount of food may vary ac- I cording to climatic conditions but ! marines abroad eat of the chow of the same quality and quantity as their buddies back home. The food which the enlisted man of today eats is as good as, if not better than, that which he had been getting in civilian life. The corps points out that the food is more wholesome because tlje in dividual is assured a scientifically balanced diet, whereas in civil life he may pick his food, ignoring vict uals that make up a proper diet. Meals in the marine corps are pre pared in smaller quantities than is usual elsewhere so that each batch is uniform. The men who prepare the foods are experts. Released by Western Newspaper Union. ---------- O ----

document.text: United States marines are rated among the best-trained soldiers in the world. One major reason for this rating is found in the basic training every marine recruit re ceives in boot camp at either Parris Island, S. C., or San Diego, Calif. Key figures in putting thousands of recruits through this rigorous six- weeks period of training are groups of versatile non-commissioned offi cers known as Drill Instructors. The DIs, as they are called, work in pairs. JCs recruits arrivé from ïvery corner of the nation, they are formed into platoons of from 66 to 74 men and each platoon is placed under the charge of a duo of DIs. It then becomes the duty of the Drill Instructors to transform some 70 men from every walk of life farmers, mechanics, accountants, reporters, truck drivers, schoolboys into a trained, disciplined group of men who walk, talk, think and act in the best marine manner. The average age of their charges is 20. And they have just six weeks for the task. The DIs must guide their men through intensive practice in drill ing, manual of arms, combat prin ciples, dressing, shooting the rifle and pistol, throwing the hand gre nade and handling the bayonet. The DIs must be good teachers in order to give instructions in first aid, field sanitation, military cour tesy, guard duty, scouting and pa trolling, security on the march and other subjects with which ev ery marine is expected to be fa miliar. They must set an example in mili tary courtesy, neatness, military bearing and countless regulation proceedings. Probably most important of all, however, the Drill Instructors teach discipline. They teach men to obey orders without question  to do what they are told, when they are told, whatever the orders may be. At the end of the boot period, the platoon of well-trained marines leaves for advanced work at special schoolsbut the DIs remain behind. They get the evening offand start in the folowing day with 66 to 74 new recruits. Released by W estern N ew spaper Union. ---------- o----------

document.text: Trophies were awarded winners in the first annual tennis tournament at Falling River Country Club on Sunday after noon. The winners, pictured above from left to right are Mark Eggleston, Tommy OBrien and Freddy Mitchell. In the final play in the Junior Division, for boys under 13 years of age, Freddy Mitchell defeated Donald Parris in sets of 6-1 and 6-3. In the Intermediate Division, ages 13 and up, Mark Eggleston defeated his brother, Mitch Eggleston, in sets of 7-5 and 7-5. In the Senior Division for adults, Tommy OBrien defeated Sam Kerr in sets of 6-0,6-4 and 6-3 to win, the trophy. FRCC plans to hold another tournament next year and will conduct the tournament play under singles elimination re gulations. Mark Weatherly is Chairman of the Tennis Com mittee.

document.text: This sumer during the week of June 23 through June 27,Fourteen 4-Hers and one adult leader from Appomattox County traveled to the Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University in Blacksburg, Virginia to take part in 4-H State Congress. This was the largest delegations from Appomattox to ever attend Congress. Approximately 1200 4-Hers throughout the state took part. During the week many activities took place. Contests such as Public Speaking, Share-the-fun, Dress Revue, Tractor Driving and Demonstrations and Illustrated Talk were among the many events that took place. Leadership classes and special classes centered around the Bicentennial were held. The election of state 4-H officers and district cabinet members were also held. The Appomattox 4-Hers took part in a variety of activities and events and came home with some state winners. Mary Parris, Cindy Guill, Charlene Rush and Debbie Rush participated in the Share - The - Fun Contest. They performed a singing act entitled, The Cloverettes in Concert. The four girls were among the five first place winners in the state. They each received a cassette tape recorder or radio. Cindy served as emcee for the contest. Nathan Smith took part in the Tractor Driving Contest. He did a great job and won 3rd place on the state level. Robert Dyess competed in a seminar program sponsored by the American Institute of Coopedratives. Roberts trip was provided by the Farmville Production Credit Association. John Jones competed in the Demonstration and Illustrated Talk Contest and the Driving Skills Contest. He gave a demonstration entitled Why A Retread May Be Your Best Buy which won him second in the state. John also won first place in the state in the Driving Skills contest. He won a trip to Richmond for the Eastern US Auto Skills Driving Contest.

document.text: The T-Rebs tied Blue Ridge Farms Monday night 6-6 in a tight game matching hard-play ing boys who had to postpone a Saturday game because of field conditions, resulting from Hur ricane Ginger.. Appomattox scored in the first quarter with co-captain Dillard Reynolds going in from 15 yards out. The extra point failed. In the second quarter Blue R i d g e Farms scored on a 40-yard pass play. They also tried a run, but the extra point feiled. In the 4th Brookville was down on the eight-yard line but stiff defense from the T- Rebs held them. Appomattox, with about two minutes left in the game, moved the ball to the 10 - yard line, but the drive failed and the boys had to come on home with a tie. Appomattox standouts on de fense were Gordon Ford, Tom my Bryant, J a m e s Rogers, Richard Blazer, Baxter Parris, Danny Scruggs and Phillip Jam erson. T-Reb standouts for the of fense included R. B. Carter, Bob Weatherly, Tim Doss, Ro bert Dyess, Ronnie Davidson and William Perdue. T-Rebs meet Rustburg here Saturday night at 8 p.m. Rust burg 11-12 year olds are un- deated 4-0 so the T-Rebs have their work cut out for them. Mites meet Rustburg at 530 p.m. with Midgets game vs Rustburg at 630 p.m. T-Rebs of Appomattox also are unde feated with 3 wins and a tie. Its gonna be a good garnet!

document.text: The marriage of Miss Kathy Faye Johnson and Mr. Donald Nelson Parris waa an event of Saturday, June 18, at three oclock in the afternoon at Bible Baptist Church in Appomattox, Virginia. Pastor Ro bert E. Lee, Jr. officiated at the ceremony. The bride is the daughter ot Mr. and Mrs. Fred D. Boone Johnson of Appomattox. The groom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Baxter Parris, Jr. of Appomattox. A program of nuptial music waa presented by Mr. Scott Drinkard of Appomattox, organist, and Miss Tamara Nash of Appomattox pianist. Vocalists were Miss Susan Johnson of Appomattox, sister of the bride, and Mr. Jane Frederick Mitchell of Hampton, VA. The bride was escorted and given in marriage by her father. The bride wore a white formal gown of bridal angel wing over bridal taffeta, featuring a high neckline and sheer sleeves gathered halfway down then fitted at the wrist. They princess style fitted bodice, the sleeves, neckline, and back seams were all accented with lace appliques covered in seed pearls and sequins. The cathedral length train was edged in lace accented with seed pearls and sequins. The cathedral length veil was accented with sequins and trimmed in lace applique covered with pearls and sequins. The headpiece waa a crown, covered with pearls and aequins. She wore a strand of pearls borrowed from Mrs. Helen Pierce, aunt of the bride. The mother of the bride designed and created the dress and headpiece. The bride carried a white Bible borrowed from Mrs. Ruth Trent, aunt of the bride. The Bible was given to Mrs. Trent by the brides grandmother 26 yean ago. It waa covered with lavender orchids, babys breath and white streamers. The treasurer reported  that we have 68.00 in our  account. The meeting was then  turned over to Mr. Sweet and 3 Mrs. Thomas. First on the ! business agenda was old I business. We discussed project i books, which should be turned tin by the end of October. The  Five County Fair was discuss- ed, Appomattox 4-ITers won  over 1,000 in prize money. document.text: The Appomattox County Chamber of Commerce will have a dinner meeting on Thurs day, June 29th, at 700 p.m. at Maudes Restaurant. Wives or husbands of members are in vited to attend. Mr. Robert P. Nelson, Ex ecutive Vice President of the Virginia Travel Council in Ri chmond, will be the guest speak er. All members are urged to be present and are asked to notify Mrs. June Chenault, Secretary of the C of C, at the Fidelity Bank regarding reservations. W. W. Blythe is President of the Chamber of Commerce in Appomattox County. 4-H Group Wins On Klassroom Kwiz rne Appomattox Community Senior 4-H Club members ap pearing on Klassroom Kwiz on Monday, June 19th, won over a team of three Boy Scouts, Or der of the Arrow, from Catawba, by a score of 150 to 140 points. The Appomattoxcontestants were behind by 20 points until the third round when one of the scouts failed to spell a word correctly and the three local contestants answered all three of their third round questions correctly. Klassroom Kwiz is seen each Monday night ot 700 p.m. on TV Channel 7, WDBJ, Roanoke. Representing the Appomattox 4-H group were David Jones, Mary Louis Parris and Mike Belter. They were awarded a check in the amount of 25.00 for their club, the prize for first place, and the chance to return next Monday night, June 26th, when they will be competing against a team from Pembrook Methodist Youth Fellowship group from Pembrook. Mr. Frank Sweet is sponsor of the Community 4-H Senior Club. Remember to tune your TV set on Monday night and support these fine young people from Appomattox.

document.text: The Appomattox Community Senior 4-H group, Mike Belter, Mary Louise Parris and David Jones, trying for their 5th con secutive win on Klassroom Kwiz on Monday night, won by a score of 200 to 140 when they were challenged by the Northside High School Key Club of Roa noke. Klassroom Kwiz is seen each Monday night on TV Channel 7 at 700 p.m. People in the area will want to be watching this 4-H group next Monday night when they will be challenged by Floyd Senior 4-H Club of Floyd. It is our understanding that next weeks team will be made up of Mike Belter, Al Johnson replacing Mary Louise Parris who will be vacationing and David Jones. The record now stands at 5 wins - with only two more chances to go. If a team wins 7 consecutive times, they are retired as Champ ions and so h r our local con testants are really going great. We wish them the best of luck next Monday, but win or lose, to us they are real  Champ ions now.

document.text: The Appomattox Community Senior 4-H Club met Monday i night. Sept. 16, at the VPI extension office. The meeting was called to order by the past secretary i Mary Parris. Frank Sweet, 4-H extension agent welcomed the new members. The first order of business was the election of the new 1974-75 4-H officers. Mary Parris was elected president, Mike Hancock, first vice-presi dent Steve Cawthorn, second vice-president Tamara Nash, secretary Pam Moore, treasur er and Joe Ford, reporter. The second order of business was the appointing of the standing committees Programs Committee - Mike Hancock and Steve Cawthorn, co-chairmen. Other members include Shenna Watts, Bill Vaughan and Judy Zimmerman. Pam Moore and Joe Ford will serve as co-chairmen of the Special Programs Committee. Karen Lively, Wendy McIn tosh, Susan Campbell, Marcella Lively, Cathy Morris and Freddy Mitchell will serve on the committee. Refreshments committee - Laurie Selz and Teresa Lively, co-chairmen. Other members include Scott Paulette, Karen Lively and Andy Pool. The Treasurers report was given by Pam Moore, it was reported that we have approxi mately 75 dollars in the checking account, and 135 dollars in the saving account, totaling 210 dollars. The Share-the-Fun program was discussed. The date of the program has been changed from the Spring to sometime in late November or early Dec ember. An exact date will be announced at a later time. Some of the members were recognized for the outstanding performances at the Five County Fair. Preparations were made for the week-end camp-out to be held Sept. 20-21-22. The next meeting was scheduled for Oct. 21. The meeting was adjourned by the newly elected president, Mary Parris.

document.text: The Appomattox Community 4-H S e n i o r s appearing on Klassroom Kwiz for their sixth consecutive tim e, lost by only 10 points on Monday night, when they were challenged by a team of Senior 4-H members from Floyd. The Appomattox team, Mike Belter, A1 Johnson replacing Mary Louise Parris who was vacationing and David Jones, ended with a score of 140 while the group from Floyd scored 150 points. Appomattox was leading in the second round of questions when George Bassett the Quiz- Master declared an answer from the Floyd team incorrect, then he had to ask for a ruling on the answer and at the end of the program it was ruled correct, thus putting the Floyd 4-Hers 10 points ahead. Our team came close to going all the way to being retired as Champions , but we are poud to say that in losing our team showed the same dignity that they had displayed when they were winning. To all of us in Appomattox, they are truly a Championship team.

document.text: The Appom attox Middle School Home Economics De partment was the setting for a surprise shower on Monday afternoon, June 5, in honor of Miss Dale Layne. Miss Layne,whose marriage to Mr. Steve Weakley will be an event of July 8, was presented with a place setting of china. In addition to the bride-elect, those in attendance were Mrs.  Hezteine Foster, principal Mr.  Lloyd Walton, superintendent and all faculty members of the school. Area Students Named To Long woods Deans List I The following students were among 330 Longwood students, in an enrollment of approxi mately 2,200 at the college-, who achieved the distinction of earning an academic average of 3.5 B from a possible 4.0 during the second semester of the college year. There were 82 students who made 4.0 or all As. From Appomattox County, named to the Deans List were Anita Lynn Glover, Beverly Dianne Harvey - 4.0, Mary Louise McCraw, and Mary Louise Parris. Founded in 1839, Longwood became fully coeducational in June of 1976, offering residence hll accomodations and all attendant services to both male and female studenta. A comprehensive institution, the . college offers majors in 30 subject areas, as well as professional training for social work, business, the health sciences and teaching.
